content.text: State how the dots on the tape show that the trolley was moving with constant speed
When the trolley reaches the point P, the ramp is tilted so that the angle \(x\) is greater
Describe and explain the change in motion of the trolley
description
explanation
Fig. 1.1 shows a trolley travelling down a ramp
The trolley has a piece of paper tape attached to it. The tape passes through a machine which makes a dot on the tape every 0.02 s
Fig. 1.2 shows a section of the tape
Another trolley is released from the top of the ramp
Fig. 1.3 shows the speed–time graph for this trolley
Using Fig. 1.3, calculate the distance travelled by the trolley in the first 0.5 s
distance =   .........
Fig. 1.4 shows a metal ball at rest in a tube of liquid
The ball is released and reaches terminal velocity at point X
Explain the motion of the ball as it falls from rest until it reaches point X
Use ideas of force and acceleration in your answer
Calculate the vertical speed of the ball as it hits the water. Air resistance can be ignored
Calculate the vertical momentum of the ball as it hits the water
momentum =   .........
Fig. 2.1 shows a cliff edge with water below it
A ball falls over the edge of the cliff. The mass of the ball is \(160 \text{g}\). The height of the cliff is \(115 \text{m}\)
Speed is a scalar quantity
State one other scalar quantity
Velocity is a vector quantity
State one other vector quantity
Calculate the time taken for the car to complete one revolution around the track
On Fig. 3.1, draw and label with the letter F an arrow to show the resultant force acting on the car
The speed of the car increases and at point P on Fig. 3.2 the car does not stay on the track
1. Suggest, in terms of the force acting on the car, why the car does not stay on the track at point P
2. On Fig. 3.2, draw and label an arrow with the letter S to show the direction of motion of the car as it leaves the track at point P
Fig. 3.1 shows a model car travelling at constant speed on a flat circular track
The speed of the car is \(0.30 \text{m/s}\). In one complete revolution around the track, the car travels \(3.9 \text{m}\)
Identify the states \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\)
Explain, in terms of forces between molecules, why gases expand more than liquids when they have the same rise in temperature. Assume that the pressure remains constant

The piston is moved to the left and fixed in a new position. The pressure of the gas in the cylinder increases to \(2.5 \times 10^{5} \text{ Pa}\). Assume that the temperature of the gas does not change
Calculate the new volume of the gas
The gas in the cylinder is now heated. The piston remains fixed in the same position as in (c)(i)
State and explain, in terms of molecules, any change in the pressure of the gas
statement
explanation
Fig. 4.2 shows a cylinder and piston
The volume of gas in the cylinder is \(3400 \text{cm}^3\). The pressure of the gas in the cylinder is \(0.90 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\)
In Fig. 4.1, the circles represent molecules in different states of matter
State and explain what happens to the pieces of cork a few minutes after the heater is switched on
Give the name of the method of transfer of thermal energy in solid metals
Fig. 5.1 shows two metal plates A and B with a radiant heater placed midway between them
Metal plate A is shiny. Metal plate B is dull black. A piece of cork is attached to each plate using wax. The wax is a solid at room temperature and has a melting point of \(37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Sound waves consist of compressions and rarefactions
Explain the terms _compression_ and _rarefaction_. Give your explanation in terms of the spacing of molecules and the pressure for sound waves in air
compression
rarefaction

wavelength =   .........
The frequency of the sound emitted by the instrument is changed to \(5.1 \text{kHz}\) and the amplitude of the sound is increased
Without calculation, state what happens to
1. the speed of the sound
2. the wavelength of the sound
A musical instrument emits a sound with a frequency of \(4.4 \text{kHz}\). The speed of sound in air is \(340 \text{m/s}\)

Suggest and explain **three** precautions for the safe use of X-rays

Fig. 8.1 shows an electrical circuit. The resistor has a resistance of \(4.0 \Omega\). The reading on the voltmeter is \(3.0 \text{V}\)
Calculate the current in the resistor
current =   .........
Fig. 8.2 shows the same circuit with one component reversed
State the reading on the voltmeter and explain your answer
reading =
explanation
Fig. 8.3 shows the symbol for a logic gate
The truth table for this logic gate is shown in Table 8.1
State the name of this logic gate
A student designs the circuit shown in Fig. 8.4
Complete the truth table for this circuit in Table 8.2
A single logic gate can be used to produce output E in Fig. 8.4 with the inputs A and B shown in Table 8.2
State the name of this logic gate
Electrical power is produced in a power station by an alternating current (a.c.) generator
The output of the generator has a voltage of \(22 000 \text{V}\). The electrical power is transmitted at a voltage of \(400 000 \text{V}\)
Explain why electrical power is transmitted at a voltage of \(400 000 \text{V}\) and not \(22 000 \text{V}\)
A computer contains a transformer
The input voltage to the transformer is \(240 \text{V}\). The output voltage from the transformer is \(20 \text{V}\) and the output current is \(2.3 \text{A}\)
The efficiency of the transformer is \(90\%\)
Calculate the input current to the transformer
current =   .........

The switch in circuit A is opened. The soft-iron armature is replaced with a steel armature. The switch in circuit A is closed
Explain what happens when the switch in circuit A is then opened

The metal plates are parallel and there is a large potential difference (p.d.) between them. Plate P is positive and plate Q is negative
On Fig. 11.1, draw the paths of each of the radiations between the plates and after leaving the plates
